message: So, obviously in Python's spirit of "batteries included" it gives you quite a bit up front.

So, this isn't immediately relevant to our site, but how often is this used to let clients manage their own content vs. simply enabling the devs (you) to crank out a high number of static pages quickly?
Usually clients will manage their own content with it.  Devs usually just write the templates, apps, plugins and have interns or other people load the content.
But, again, this could be where I'm missing something deeper with django-cms
I've only played with it a bit

So when you said "it really shines with static content", it seems it would be more accurate to say it shines when having users *manage* static content. I mean, static content is already easy with django templates.
it really doesn't pertain much to the site we're gonna build I guess
sure, thousands, but that's still having the client/users manage it, right?
yeah.  but the other option would be to have devs manage it
I need to start working on a presentation on it
a little bit of content is easy to manage.  try a site with a thousand pages of content
yeah, that looks like the perfect situation for it :)
the nice thing about django-cms for me, and I guess the projects I'm involved in at work, is how easy you can integrate your own apps with all the standard cms functionality

I guess, so far at least, the sites I've worked on have been more about specialized workflows than lots of content. I'm imagining that when I do get into the situation you describe I'd be loving it too.
